headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: Soon: Zelenskyy Heads To Capitol Hill With Ukraine Aid At Risk; Showcasing The Positivity Of Hip-Hop Culture; "Jose Andres & Family In Spain" Airs Sunday At 9PM ET/PT. Aired 7:30-8a ET

utterances.speaker: PHIL MATTINGLY, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: And joining us now is CNN's chief international anchor, Christine Amanpour.The contrast of the reception --

utterances.speaker: CHRISTIANE AMANPOUR, CNN CHIEF INTERNATIONAL ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: -- not just going back to March, which was a video speech that he gave, but late last year when he was in person and it was very dramatic from both sides of the aisle, that shift -- is this a political issue right now or is it deeper than that?

utterances.speaker: AMANPOUR
utterances.sentences: You know, it's hard to tell. Obviously, politicians react to their people. You've seen some of the polls that have come not just here, in Europe as well. President Zelenskyy spoke to a much less full house than the last time he addressed the U.N. Biden and Zelenskyy stood very firm at the U.N. this week. It was a week of solidarity for the protection of democracy against dictatorship and autocracy. And so they need to keep making their case.It is not surprising that he's not again being asked to deliver -- to address a joint session. That's not surprising. The question is will the United States' commitment from the administration continue -- i.e., that we will support Ukraine for as long as it takes? President Biden wants to, I believe, deliver another $24 billion in military --

utterances.speaker: POPPY HARLOW, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: That's right. AMANPOURClearly, in the Senate, the minority leader -- Republican leader Mitch McConnell is very pro-defense of freedom and sovereignty for Ukraine.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You've been back and back to Ukraine reporting --

utterances.speaker: AMANPOUR
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: -- from the ground during this war. Just explain to people what happens if Congress doesn't re-up funding.

utterances.speaker: AMANPOUR
utterances.sentences: Well, you can see what's happening now, to be frank. The American administration has given an enormous amount of aid over the last year and a half. It has created and sustained an incredible and unprecedented alliance that is still firm despite all the chit-chat and chatter on the -- on the outskirts.But the fact that the counteroffensive is not going as it was way too highly touted -- by the way, expectations were raised to here --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: AMANPOUR
utterances.sentences: -- and they will never match that. It is a slow, long slog.But without the proper weaponry at the right time, it's just a simple equation. If you don't have it you can't do it. And so, they need to get more of the correct weaponry. And you say today -- I mean, the Russians -- they don't do things by accident -- this massive barrage against the capital, Kyiv. Obviously, great -- the anti-missile systems that the U.S. and others have sent keep getting most of them but not all of them. You know, they can take down most of these things but not all of them. And we're starting maybe another six weeks maybe of fighting season and then there's the winter. Then there's the whole thing about bashing civilian infrastructure again --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: AMANPOUR
utterances.sentences: -- and the cycle continues.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Zelenskyy is in town -- or in the United States because of the U.N. General Assembly.

utterances.speaker: AMANPOUR
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Most people think of this week in New York, in part, for the traffic but also because there are critical speeches from world leaders throughout the course of the week. It also means that you have interviews with, like, 600 really important people.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Basically, it --

utterances.speaker: AMANPOUR
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: It's basically everyone.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Every single important topic in geopolitics.You also -- in this case, you spoke to Al Gore --

utterances.speaker: AMANPOUR
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: -- the former vice president. What did he say?

utterances.speaker: AMANPOUR
utterances.sentences: Well, he is the major grand -- I was going to say grand dame but, of course, he's a guy. He's the major leader of the climate activist movement worldwide.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Oh, I -- can we play --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Should we listen to him?

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Yeah, sorry.

utterances.speaker: AMANPOUR
utterances.sentences: Well, sure. Let's do it.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: AL FORE, FORMER VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: And one of the reasons why President Biden became president was his advocacy for solutions to the climate crisis.

utterances.speaker: AMANPOUR
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GORE
utterances.sentences: And what he has presided over is the passage of, by far, the biggest and best climate legislation that any country has ever passed in history. He's done some things I don't agree with but what he has done in a positive way far outweighs the rest. He has been a genuine leader on this issue. And the Congress passed the IRA. It's going to put more than a trillion dollars into speeding up the deployment of alternative sources of energy.

utterances.speaker: AMANPOUR
utterances.sentences: And what happens if a Donald Trump comes back?

utterances.speaker: GORE
utterances.sentences: Oh, I --

utterances.speaker: AMANPOUR
utterances.sentences: We saw the --

utterances.speaker: GORE
utterances.sentences: I'm not even going to speculate on that.

utterances.speaker: AMANPOUR
utterances.sentences: On climate -- or somebody like him with those views.

utterances.speaker: GORE
utterances.sentences: I don't like to speculate on that for the same reason I don't like to watch horror movies.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: I mean, you could have let him go after I don't like to speculate -- AMANPOUR

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: -- but you pressed him and you got him -- you got him over the --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Whoa!

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: -- there. You got him over the line.

utterances.speaker: AMANPOUR
utterances.sentences: I did.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: What was your takeaway both on the analysis of the climate efforts --

utterances.speaker: AMANPOUR
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: -- from the Biden administration --

utterances.speaker: AMANPOUR
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: -- but also I think he gets at a critical element --

utterances.speaker: AMANPOUR
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: -- behind the scenes --

utterances.speaker: AMANPOUR
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: -- and on (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: AMANPOUR
utterances.sentences: So he was very upset about that.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Which he'd been warning of.

utterances.speaker: AMANPOUR
utterances.sentences: Yeah. And, of course, it's -- he's just trying to say don't play politics with this existential threat. And we've all been reporting on it. CNN has been doing breaking news for weeks and months of the terrible weather all over the world and all over this country.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Another -- MATTINGLY

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Interesting.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Let me ask --

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Just stay. Don't go back.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Christiane told us she's flying home --

utterances.speaker: AMANPOUR
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: -- after this and we're sad because we've gotten you at the table for a week.

utterances.speaker: AMANPOUR
utterances.sentences: Well, it's been my pleasure.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: AMANPOUR
utterances.sentences: Next time, yeah.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: All right. This week, CNN is bringing you a series that we love called "Champions for Change" -- stories of everyday people who embody humanity at its best with new ideas that are leading to great changes.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Now, of course, hip-hop involves rhythm, wit, and a whole lot of creativity. I had to define that for you. Listen to hip-hop, please.Victor Blackwell's champion is tapping into the power of hip-hop to stretch young people's minds. He calls the innovative gatherings Soul Food Cyphers. And Victor Blackwell joins us now -- Victor.

utterances.speaker: VICTOR BLACKWELL, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: This was fun to shoot. It was a really good time and they're doing some great work with Soul Food Cyphers. So my champion is Alex Acosta, also known as "Cost One." And this is a great example of a man who took his passion -- one of his loves and "hmm, I wonder if that would work" moment and created something that I think is extraordinary -- watch.(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I see the way you're rapping. Embracing the freestyle. I see just how it happens.BLACKWELL (on camera):  So I chose this story first because I love the art form. I love the music. Hip-hop and rap have been the soundtrack of my teen years, my 20s, 30s, and now 40s, too.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Call me Jetson. Oh, like I'm Elroy.BLACKWELL (on camera):  And often when we see these cyphers or we see or hear hip-hop or rap people assume that it's negative. But in these cyphers, that's not what we see. What we see is people telling their truths, and sometimes they are difficult but these are loving spaces.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It's so real it stopped the lungs. You're giving it to them and you want some. Hey, you (INAUDIBLE) want some.

utterances.speaker: ALEX ACOSTA, COMMUNITY LEADER, ARTS ADVOCATE, FOUNDING EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR OF SOUL FOOD CYPHER
utterances.sentences: Yeah. Juveniles want some. I'm going to switch it up.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: OK.BLACKWELL (voice-over):  Alex, also known as "Cost One," creates this safe space where people feel comfortable to talk about what is happening in their lives and where they want to go. It's aspirational as well. BLACKWELL (on camera):  Tell me about how you got to not just loving the cypher, loving hip-hop --

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: Yeah.BLACKWELL (on camera):  -- but doing something with it. Where did that start?

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: I realized that there was a magic there. By design, cyphers are ephemeral. They pop up and then they dissipate. Why not create a permanent cypher? So I brought some of my best friends together and we created Soul Food Cypher.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: (Rapping).

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: Our organization has been around for 11 years and we look to showcase the positive elements of hip-hop culture through our cypher events and also our workshops and performances as well.So a lot of times, rap music, especially popular mainstream, et cetera, et cetera -- the music and the message that you hear justifies a historical negative that Black men are violent, misogynistic, Black women are overly sexualized, XYZ. So why is the lyrical content important? It's important that we change that narrative. BLACKWELL (on camera):  Outside of the monthly cyphers, Soul Food Cypher goes into schools, and this is the part that I think is the most fantastic. What I've learned also from some of the instructors is that it helps them grow as well. BUNDUKE, TEACHING ARTIST, SOUL FOOD CYPHER:  As we go through the curriculum and I'm teaching them and allowing them to express these gifts that are already inside of them, they get this feeling and it builds a connection. It builds a bond. They'll share some things that's, like, crazy. And it's like dang, that's what you're going through at home, you know? And they'll be like oh, can you come to my soccer game? Nobody comes to my soccer game. Bro, I used to be that. Like, that's just crazy to me, man. So I'm, like, I've got to come back. BLACKWELL (on camera):  You get, obviously, a lot out of it as much as you give to these students. Speak to the question of why it's important to pass the art form to the next generation.

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: We're using this English language in order to be able to inspire influence because sometimes, our voice is the only thing we do have. But then you're reminded by instructor Bunduke, Ana (PH), Brad (PH) from Soul Food Cypher that you have a power and that your voice matters.We're building community and we're building rapport between people, and it's a very, very powerful thing to have, like hip-hop church. You're going to see love and you're going to see respect, knowledge, and joy. You're going to see smiles. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: That's so good. It's like the best part of every day --

utterances.speaker: BLACKWELL
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: -- this week. And Victor, that was absolutely outstanding. Victor Blackwell --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yeah. MATTINGLY

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I loved it.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: And you should -- as we've reminded you every day this week, be sure to tune in Saturday at 8

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Also new this morning, Hollywood going back to the negotiating table. What we're hearing about a potential deal to end the writer's strike.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Plus, Jose Andres has spent more than a decade helping to feed millions of people facing humanitarian, climate, and community crises. There's a reason. His new cookbook is called "Feeding Humanity, Feeding Hope." We're going to talk to him about it live -- his new CNN series. That's next. Stay with us.(COMMERCIAL)

utterances.speaker: JOSE ANDRES, CHEF, AUTHOR, HUMANITARIAN, FOUNDER, JOSE ANDRES GROUP
utterances.sentences: My girls have a sweet tooth and, of course, they are look for something sugary to start their day. In Barcelona, the obvious choice is the chucho.CARLOTA ANDRES, ANDRES' DAUGHTER:  Oh, the chucho. J. ANDRES:  And what is a chucho? C. ANDRES:  A croissant? J. ANDRES:  Carlota, what? No! C. ANDRES:  (INAUDIBLE). J. ANDRES:  Take a look. This is like this amazing dough that is fried and filled up with cream. Not just any cream, Crema Catalana. Almost like a sweet, velvety custard with sugar dusted on the crunchy outside. A good croissant is a great thing, lady, but a chucho -- a chucho is for the gods.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: How is it, Carlota?C. ANDRES:  Oh my god.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Oh my god, your lip's all sugary.C. ANDRES:  It's so creamy and crunchy, and sweet. The chucho -- oh my gosh. The chuchos are the best thing in the world.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Why are croissants everywhere in America? Why can't chuchos be everywhere in America?C. ANDRES:  I think we should take chuchos to the U.S. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: That's just asking the right questions, right there.Joining us now is award-winning chef, author, and humanitarian, Jose Andres. Thanks so much for being here and for being at the table. As the president of the White House Council on Sports, Fitness & Nutrition, I very much appreciate what you brought in today.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Were you -- were you really?

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: No, I wasn't. He is.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: But you really were that?

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: No. He is literally President Biden's --J. ANDRES:  Yeah.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: He's -- that's what he was.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I thought Phil was talking about himself. I know. I remember.J. ANDRES:  No. I am, but this is only to showcase --

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Yeah, we appreciate it -- yes.J. ANDRES:  -- my country.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Yeah. It's purely -- yes.J. ANDRES:  If you eat with moderation, everything is great.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: No chuchos there, yeah?

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: The genesis of this idea -- like, especially with the kids going back to your home country -- where did it come from? J. ANDRESThis show, in a way, is opening a door, it's opening a window, it's building bridges between America and Spain.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: When you were with us almost a year ago when this was launching on Discovery+, you talked about what it meant to you as a father to do this with your daughters. To see the world in this way through their eyes -- what you have dedicated your life to.J. ANDRES:  Obviously, my daughters feel somewhat like they have the perfect switch in the way they behave when they are in the states and the way they behave when they go back to Spain where their mother and myself come from. And for me, taking my daughters -- which they've been going every summer to Spain -- but take them to all the places. Spain is a small country but then, like everywhere, is a big country. And take them to new places and use -- show them the places that grow up as a young schoolboy going to culinary school. For me, this was the most amazing moment -- not so much a show of travel and food but at the end, that the daughters having a great time together. We even went shooting this show to Ukraine. You mentioned the missiles.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes, you did.J. ANDRES:  I took one of my daughters with me to Ukraine where missiles already began falling down -- going back last year in March- April. So you see life is celebrating the good moments but then keeping in touch with the reality that the world is a complicated place. But here, what we are doing is completely celebrating family.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: And you're so intentional about bringing local food to those local areas of disaster so people really feel that comfort from it and it's not something foreign to them.J. ANDRES:  But it's also the smart thing to do.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yeah.J. ANDRES:  What really do you have when you go to --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Of course.J. ANDRES:  -- to Haiti? There, the ingredients of Haiti.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yeah.J. ANDRES:  And the people of Haiti -- what they know what to cook. The traditional Haitian dishes. So it makes sense. It's logical. That's what we do.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: We are so glad you're here taking action. I know you've called on leaders at the U.N. General Assembly this week not just to give these speeches but to take real action. Thank you for what you do.J. ANDRES:  Thank you.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: And congrats. We can't wait to have it here on CNN.J. ANDRES:  All right. I'm happy to be part of the family.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Oh, good.Be sure to tune in as CNN presents a Discovery+ original "JOSE ANDRES AND FAMILY IN SPAIN." It is Sunday, 9:00 PM Eastern and Pacific right here.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Well, new and disturbing allegations against Rudy Giuliani. A former White House aide and star witness in the January 6 hearings is now claiming she was groped on the day of the insurrection. We'll have those details ahead.(COMMERCIAL)
